titles.title: Seated Woman and Satyr on Clouds

makers.displaydate: 1696–1770; born Venice, Italy; died Madrid, Spain
makers.displaymaker: Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, 1696–1770; born Venice, Italy; died Madrid, Spain

texts.textentryhtml: Arthur L. Frothingham (1859-1923); possibly by descent to his sister Jessie Peabody Frothingham (1862-1949); purchased by Frank Jewett Mather, Jr.; gifted to Princeton University Art Museum, 1944.
texts.remarks: reformatted and Frothingham siblings' dates added by Emma Holter (summer intern 2025)

texts.textentryhtml: The most celebrated artist of eighteenth-­century Venice, Giovanni Battista Tiepolo was also the last major exponent of the grand tradition of fresco decoration, into which he breathed new life with his seemingly inexhaustible imagination — described by one contemporary as "all spirit and fire." His brilliant draftsmanship is evident in this effervescent pen and wash sketch, one of a large group of studies that have been connected with the Course of the Chariot of the Sun, an allegorical ceiling fresco in the Palazzo Clerici, Milan. With a swift succession of spare black chalk strokes, pen and ink contours, transparent golden washes, and exuberant darker brown accents, Tiepolo conjures up this languid and lofty couple. Suspended in a seductive realm of dazzling luminosity, their airy forms contrast dramatically with the whiteness of the paper.
